sen.e: The number describes an exchange between Tarokaja (a common name for a manservant in Kyogen, Noh farce), who tries to get sake for free, and owner of sake shop who tries to prevent it.

sen.j: ある日の急な来客に、家の主は太郎冠者を呼びつけ、酒屋へいって酒を貰ってくるよう命じた。
sen.e: One day, a master called Tarokaja and told to go sake shop to get sake, for a unexpected visitor.

sen.j: しかし、太郎冠者は「前の支払いが終わっていないので、きっと譲ってはくれないでしょう」と諫言する。
sen.e: However Tarokaja remonstrate saying 'I do not think sake shop owner will give sake this time, as the last payment is not yet finished'.

sen.j: 主はうまく取ってこられたら褒美をやると約束し、太郎冠者を無理矢理追い立てた。
sen.e: The master pushes Tarokaja to go to sake shop promising a reward if he can get sake.

sen.e: However, as expected, sake shop owner flatly rejects saying he cannot give sake unless the last payment is finished.

sen.j: 思案した太郎冠者は珍品を好む酒屋の主人に面白い話を聞かせ、その隙をついて酒をかっぱらう事を思いつく。
sen.e: After much consideration, Tarokaja think of snatching sake while telling a funny story to sake shop owner, who favors something rare.

sen.e: Tarokaja decided to tell 'story of catching Charadriidae seen in Tsushima Matsuri (Tsushima Festival, a religious festival of Tsushima-jinja Shrine)', and started shikatabanashi (talking with gestures).

sen.j: 酒屋の主人に囃させ、謡い舞いながら隙を見て酒樽に手をかける。
sen.e: Tarokaja makes sake shop owner to beat time, and he watch for a chance and tries to snatch a sake cask while singing and dancing.

sen.e: Tarokaja tries to draw attention again by talking about yabusame (horseback archery), but now cautious sake shop owner reminded Tarokaja not to use sake cask in the story.

sen.e: Tarokaja get astride on wooden stick and picks up sake cask while turning around once, imitating a horseman of yabusame, and runs for his life.
